reviewText: I love Bill Maher. I love his sense of humor, his timing and mugging, and frankly, I like his looks plenty, too. But how will I review this DVD, which is actually a collection of the "New Rule" segment from his first four seasons on HBO, including a few special longer editorials with a relatively serious format that start with New Rule and then go on to editorialize in a pretty direct fashion.I've recently been reading a book about the serious philosophical roots of this sort of humor. Did you know it began with Socrates? It's true. Not that I claim Bill Maher or any of these lovable crazies are intentionally using techniques they learned in philosophy school. But the serious side of what they achieve involves a rather long history of social commentary by way of humor.Since these "New Rules" came from 2006 and earlier, the primary target is, not surprisingly, George Bush. But it's by no means all political. There are segments about many different aspects of American life. I'm not going to mention any, because (1) I have a lousy memory, and would screw it up, and (2) Maher does it so much better. I'll just suggest that if you get a chance to see this DVD, take it.
summary: Liberals Will Laugh, Conservatives Will Throw Things

reviewText: On a broader plain than his closest competition (Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert), comedian Bill Maher skewers absurdities beyond the well-trodden political arena into the media-friendly dimensions of American life with a bracing candor and wit. Too controversial for ABC or even Comedy Central, Maher moved to HBO in 2003 with a revised program, "Real Time With Bill Maher". He developed a regular segment called "New Rules" where he singles out public behavior that he acknowledges is wrong or at least questionable. This 2006 DVD culls three seasons worth of "New Rules" to end up as a "best-of" compilation.It sounds like it would be wearing to listen to a series of satirical rants from Maher. However, not having been a regular viewer of "Real Time", I am struck by how often he hits his targets with vitriolic accuracy and adroit humor. There are too many hilarious segments to single out, but my personal favorites involve gay fraternities, the correlation between body fat and Scientology, the irritating stickers on individual pieces of fruit, the Village People-wannabe clothing of George W., the excrements of seeing-eye dogs, and the pop-up ads for Classmates.com. Inevitably, there are some bits that already feel dated like ridiculing the "Friends" finale and freedom fries. The program includes staged inserts to break up Maher's talking-head comments, such as a terror alert under the guise of an innocuous weather forecast.It was smart of the producers to limit the running time of the main program to 45 minutes because any longer would be too exhausting. On the upside, there is a half-hour's worth of extras. There are some "New Rules" that simply did not make the final cut though they are just about as funny. Even better are four editorial segments that come across as more fully developed comedy bits, as Maher covers topics such as same-sex marriage, the indiscriminate use of wolves in Bush's political ads, gays in the military, and of course, the need for a Bush recall movement. It's all hilarious, often sharply insightful and a great way to enjoy Maher's humor without paying the premium price of HBO.
summary: Maher's Skillful Skewering Captured Neatly on a Compact DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: I already own the NEW RULES audiobook, which was recorded by Bill Maher in a studio without an audience.  With roughly three hours of material, the audiobook is the most comprehensive persentation of Bill's numerous new rules (not to mention I'd rather hear the material in Maher's own voice than read the printed version).  The new rules on this DVD -- totaling 45 minutes not including extras -- frequently overlaps what's in the book, which itself at times reprised the material from the original HBO broadcasts which comprise this DVD.  Either way, the point is that most of the rules will be familiar to anyone who has read or heard the book (and it goes without saying to those who've watched the broadcasts on HBO).I agree with other reviewers who have criticized the relatively high list price and/or the incomplete presentation of what was originally broadcasted in the "new rules" segment of the first three seasons of his HBO show.  Yet when I get to the bottom line -- is this DVD funny? -- in my opinion the answer is consistently yes.  The edits from gag to gag are as smooth as can be, and there's several bits of other material from his show to offer comic relief -- so to speak -- from the "new rules" segments.  Even if you know the "punch line" of the rules, the inspired rapport that Bill has with his studio audience carries over to the DVD, making it an entertaining option for those of us who enjoy Bill's not-PC humor (which is not surprisingly rated TV-MA).  Although I'd recommend his live performance DVDs first, NEW RULES is a welcome addition to what is available by Bill Maher on video.
summary: NEW RULES: Got Live If You Want It ...
Title: N/A

reviewText: The three star rating that I am giving this DVD is no way indicative of the material that this DVD presents.  The strong political humor that is brought to the table by Bill Maher is top notch.  No, the reason this DVD gets three stars is because of the price in relation to the length of the DVD.  Buying this DVD is like buying a lesser version of an SNL Best Of...  The clips on this DVD are from Bill Maher's HBO television show, and on this show is a segment called New Rules, hence the name.  The DVD presents New Rules (not all of them, but rather a selection of the best of the best) from seasons 1-3, as well as a few fake commercials and skits thrown in now and then.  The jokes contained in this segment are raunchy, offensive, and aimed towards right-wing conservatives, mostly the president.  During a skit in which Maher is being tortured for making fun of the president, he makes promises to marry Ann Coulter, at which point a black bag is placed over his head and a butchy-looking female soldier steps into the picture, indicative of Abu Ghraib.  This DVD is not for the easily offended, or the Republican.  The DVD is only 45 minutes long, which is why I caution you to only purchase this if you are a strong fan of Maher and his show.  Otherwise, rental stores are receiving limited amounts of the DVD, and it might be worth a rent.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm always sad when "New Rules" comes on at the end of "Real Time With Bill Maher" because it means that's the end of the show. Since the latest season is over now, I needed my Bill Maher fix. Funny stuff here. The one about "Let Freedom Jiggle" made me laugh so hard just from the title alone. He should be eating crow right now for his comment about Demi Moore and Ashton Kutcher because they're still together, but I understand the skepticism. I definitely co-sign with tipping at Starbucks. I have yet to find a reason for all of those tipping jars. I'm looking forward to seeing more "New Rules."
summary: 'Let Freedom Jiggle' did it for me
Title: N/A
